repnme.cdata!:
Equipping Moldova to respond to infectious
            disease outbreaks

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile is about equipping
            Moldova to respond to infectious disease outbreaks. In 2005,
            a series of avian flu outbreaks near Moldova's western
            border resulted in the culling of thousands of birds.
            Moldova's laboratory equipment was outdated. Its
            medical and veterinary personnel had little training and
            experience detecting the virus, and the public was poorly
            aware of risk associated with avian flu and other infectious
            diseases. What's more, there was little compensation
            for farmers whose chickens had to be culled. All of this
            presented a big challenge to an effective government
            response. At the request of the Government of Moldova, the
            World Bank stepped in to coordinate a multi-donor effort to
            strengthen Moldova's capacity to respond and mitigate
            outbreaks of avian influenza and other infections, and
            increase the country's preparedness for possible
            pandemics. On the human health side, the renovation of an
            intensive care unit within the premises of the National
            Infectious Diseases Hospital has meant that every Moldovan
            infected with a deadly strain of influenza virus has a
            better chance of survival. The project's lasting effect
            is that it has also managed to change people's
            attitudes and behavior when it comes to prevention of
            infectious diseases. Extensive communication and public
            awareness campaigns targeted all age groups and stimulated a
            high level of social awareness.

docna.cdata!:
Echiparea Republicii Moldova pentru a putea
            face față epidemiilor de boli infecțioase

display_title.display_title:
Equipping Moldova to respond to
            infectious disease outbreaks : Echiparea Republicii Moldova

repnme.cdata!:
Equipping Moldova to respond to infectious
            disease outbreaks

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            equipping Moldova to respond to infectious disease
            outbreaks. When avian flu outbreaks in 2005 hit Central and
            Eastern Europe governments, healthcare and veterinary
            institutions went on high alert. Avian Influenza Project
            strengthened Moldova's capacity to respond and mitigate
            outbreaks of avian influenza and other infections, and
            increase the country's preparedness for possible
            pandemics. A full-fledged rehabilitation of Moldova's
            main human and animal virology labs was done to diagnose
            viruses in people and animals. The World Bank joined with
            the government to establish streamlined and transparent
            compensation mechanisms to assist farmers whose chickens had
            to be culled. The project's lasting effect was that it
            had also managed to change people's attitudes and
            behavior when it comes to prevention of infectious diseases.

Equipping Moldova to respond to infectious

repnme.cdata!:
Moldova - Avian Influenza Control and Human
            Pandemic Preparedness and Response Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Avian Influenza
            Control and Human Pandemic Preparedness and Response Project
            for Moldova is to minimize the threat posed to humans by
            Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza (HPAI) and other
            infectious diseases that originate in animals. The closing
            date for the project will be extended from March 31, 2011
            until May 15, 2011. The extension is necessary to allow more
            time for the completion of supply and installation of IT
            equipment for an epidemiological surveillance system devised
            under the project's human health component. The basic
            design and operationalization of the system occurred in
            2009, but some further adjustments and physical expansion
            where necessary to enhance its ability to cover not just
            avian influenza but a broad spectrum of viral infections.
            Furthermore, a push was made to pilot the system in one
            district not just at preventive medicine entities, but at
            all public health institutions. Unfortunately, the failure
            of one supplier to deliver on time the necessary IT
            equipment for the physical expansion of the system resulted
            in a highly-probable risk of incompletion of this important
            activity before closing. This will result in an unfortunate
            penalization of the Beneficiary, which has throughout
            implementation has demonstrated a strong commitment to the
            project's objectives. The Beneficiary does not have own
            resources to finance the procurement of the IT equipment in
            question. The extension will allow for the supply and
            installation of goods to be completed with financing from
            the Project, while enabling the client to successfully
            achieve the system's necessary operating expansion.

display_title.display_title:
Moldova - Avian Influenza Control
            and Human Pandemic Preparedness and Response Project :
            restructuring : Main report

repnme.cdata!:
Moldova - Avian Influenza Control and Human
            Pandemic Preparedness and Response Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Avian Influenza
            Control and Human Pandemic Preparedness and Response Project
            for Moldova is to minimize the threat posed to humans by
            Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza (HPAI) and other
            infectious diseases that originate in animals. All planned
            activities will be completed before the closing date of
            March 31, 2011. As of January 15, 2011, the project has
            disbursed US$8.85 million of its overall financing envelope,
            including US$7.4 million of International Development
            Association (IDA) grant and credit (88 percent), and is
            expected to disburse 100 percent of proceeds by closing. The
            reallocation is necessary to finance a few final activities
            aimed at strengthening the project's development
            impact. The activities are: (i) expansion of the
            epidemiological surveillance system for infectious diseases
            and related user training; (ii) procurement of server
            software licenses for the system; (iii) procurement of a
            sampling truck for the Republican Veterinary Diagnostic
            Center; and (iv) implementation of a knowledge and practices
            survey amongst the public and health and veterinary
            professionals on matters related to avian, pandemic, and
            seasonal influenza.

repnme.cdata!:
Moldova - Avian Influenza Control and Human
            Pandemic Preparedness and Response Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Avian Influenza
            Control and Human Pandemic Preparedness and Response Project
            for Moldova is to minimize the threat posed to humans by
            Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza (HPAI) and other
            infectious diseases that originate in animals. The
            reallocation is necessary to continue the support under the
            project's animal health component for activities aimed
            at strengthening the diagnosis capacity of the Republican
            Center for Veterinary Diagnostics (RCVD). The reallocation
            will allow for the financing of one significant additional
            output, the refurbishment of the Central Veterinary
            Laboratory (CVL) of the RCVD. This important work was
            supposed to be completed till 2007 with funding from the
            Government's own budget in order to complement the
            project's focus on strengthening the country's
            capacity for animal health diagnosis. However, the
            Government was unable to fund the refurbishment of the CVL
            due to severe budget spending constraints in recent years.
            The civil works and equipment involved, costing an estimated
            US$1.5 million, comprise the installation of new utilities
            (water, gas, heating, electricity) in the entire building
            and of an elevator, as well as the refurbishment of interior
            walls and floors to ensure essential hygiene in the
            laboratory. In addition, the project will support the
            installation of a medium capacity incinerator to ensure the
            secure disposal of biological waste. Completing these works
            and acquiring the necessary equipment will ensure that the
            building of the CVL is structurally sound and all its
            sections are up to date with respect to basic laboratory
            sanitary, safety and utility requirements, efficient
            workflows, and effective provision of enabling conditions
            for the diagnosis of highly pathogenic avian influenza. In
            addition, these activities will ensure that all prior
            support provided by the project and other donors for
            strengthening CVL's diagnosis capacity will be
            safeguarded against possible physical deterioration of the building.

            installation of a medium capacity incinerator to ensure the
            secure disposal of biological waste. Completing these works
            and acquiring the necessary equipment will ensure that the
            building of the CVL is structurally sound and all its
            sections are up to date with respect to basic laboratory
            sanitary, safety and utility requirements, efficient
            workflows, and effective provision of enabling conditions
            for the diagnosis of highly pathogenic avian influenza. In
            addition, these activities will ensure that all prior
            support provided by the project and other donors for
            strengthening CVL's diagnosis capacity will be
            safeguarded against possible physical deterioration of the building.
